comments:
This final clinical nursing course focuses on the integration and synthesis of
scientific knowledge with clinical nursing practice and the development of the
professional nursing role. Building on content from prior courses, students develop an
understanding of management of patient care from the perspective of the individual client
and family to groups of clients and eventually to management of health care systems.
Principles of leadership, accountability and change are integrated throughout. The
process of transition from the student role to that of the professional nurse is facilitated
through discussion of organizational systems, professional issues, mechanisms for
evaluation of care and the role of the nurse as patient advocate and change agent.
Students select from several practice options for the clinical content of the course.
Clinical seminar content builds on core content and provides an exposure to advanced
nursing concepts within the area of specialty practice. Application of conceptual models
to clinical practice is discussed and nursing research is integrated throughout the course.
Most reviews reflected that this course was extremely useful for students about to
graduate and enter the nursing field. The class was described as “wonderful” and having
provided “valuable exercises.” Many of the lectures involved case studies that students
felt enhanced their understanding, and the guest speakers that presented the case studies
were greatly enjoyed. The most common criticism was the structure of the class; many
would have preferred more of a seminar or discussion based class instead of a lecture.
Students described the professor as “engaging” and “informative.” Although students did
not seek out assistance often, they found the instructors willing to aid if students were
struggling with the material.
Students found this course to be challenging. Despite the substantial amounts of
work, students felt more prepared for professional nursing after taking the course. Often
students felt that their grades were not reflective of the amount of effort they put into the
class or of the amount of knowledge they took away from the course.

This final clinical nursing course focuses on the integration and synthesis of
scientific knowledge with clinical nursing practice and the development of the
professional nursing role. Building on content from prior courses, students develop an
understanding of management of patient care from the perspective of the individual client
and family to groups of clients and eventually to management of health care systems.
Principles of leadership, accountability and change are integrated throughout. The
process of transition from the student role to that of the professional nurse is facilitated
through discussion of organizational systems, professional issues, mechanisms for
evaluation of care and the role of the nurse as patient advocate and change agent.
Students select from several practice options for the clinical content of the course.
Clinical seminar content builds on core content and provides an exposure to advanced
nursing concepts within the area of specialty practice. Application of conceptual models
to clinical practice is discussed and nursing research is integrated throughout the course.
Students seem to be split in their evaluation of this course. Some students felt that
the course was disorganized and “did not prepare them for the transition between nursing
student and nurse.” However, others really enjoyed the course and found it “extremely
relevant” to their future practice.
This course is the final clinical piece of undergraduate nursing. It is typically taken
in the last semester of senior year.
